title: Subdued, a TMEM16 family Ca<sup>2+</sup>-activated Cl<sup>âˆ’</sup> channel in <italic>Drosophila melanogaster</italic> with an unexpected role in host defense
abstract: TMEM16A and TMEM16B are calcium-activated chloride channels (CaCCs) with important functions in mammalian physiology. Whether distant relatives of the vertebrate TMEM16 families also form CaCCs is an intriguing open question. Here we report that a TMEM16 family member from <italic>Drosophila melanogaster</italic>, Subdued (CG16718), is a CaCC. Amino acid substitutions of Subdued alter the ion selectivity and kinetic properties of the CaCC channels heterologously expressed in HEK 293T cells. This <italic>Drosophila</italic> channel displays characteristics of classic CaCCs, thereby providing evidence for evolutionarily conserved biophysical properties in the TMEM16 family. Additionally, we show that knockout flies lacking <italic>subdued</italic> gene activity more readily succumb to death caused by ingesting the pathogenic bacteria <italic>Serratia marcescens</italic>, suggesting that <italic>subdued</italic> has novel functions in <italic>Drosophila</italic> host defense.
